title: WeWork bonds plummet the most on record after the company delays its IPO
text:
Jackal Pan/Reuters

WeWork's delayed initial public offering sent its bonds tumbling on Tuesday as the company's streak of bad news continues.

The shared-workspace company's $669 million of bonds expiring in 2025 fell by as much as 7 cents on the dollar, to 95.8 cents. The drop was the biggest since the notes' April 2018 issuance.

WeWork said on Monday that it now expects to go public before the end of the year.

Visit the Markets Insider homepage for more stories.

WeWork's delayed initial public offering sent its bonds plummeting the most on record on Tuesday as the company's streak of bad news continues.

The shared-workspace company's $669 million of 2025 bonds fell by as much as 7 cents on the dollar, to 95.8 cents, according to Bloomberg data. The drop was the biggest since the notes' April 2018 issuance.

"The We Co. is looking forward to our upcoming IPO, which we expect to be completed by the end of the year," the company said in a Monday statement.

Investors fear that the company's postponed offering will endanger its ability to pay back its debt. The company needs to go public before the end of the year if it wants to receive a $6 billion credit facility contingent on a successful IPO, Bloomberg reported.

Read more: JPMorgan unveils 6 trades that should rake in profits regardless of whether the stock market tanks or rebounds in the near future

The IPO was set to be the second biggest of 2019, after Uber's $8.1 billion listing in May. WeWork was valued at $47 billion following a private fundraising round in January but recently trimmed its public valuation to between $10 billion and $12 billion, according to Reuters.

The lowered target arrived after experts questioned the company's profitability, market size, and position in the tech community.

WeWork was scheduled to begin its IPO roadshow as soon as this week.

SeaWorld suffers biggest plunge of 2019 as CEO resigns after just 7 months
